facts.fact: Beavers are rodents and belong to the same family as rats and mice. But they are much bigger! An adult beaver can weigh the same as 1,500 little mice.
A beaver’s home is called a lodge. Lodges are little dome-shaped houses made from woven sticks, grasses and moss plastered with mud.
Beavers slap their tails on the water to indicate danger.

Nose and ear valves shut to keep out water while beavers are submerged, and nictitating membranes (transparent "third eyelids") act as goggles. Their lips close behind their oversized front teeth, allowing beavers to transport building materials and food without drowning.

Some beavers have orange teeth. This is because, whereas other rodents have magnesium in their tooth enamel, beavers have iron. So beavers have orange teeth for the same reason we have red blood. The iron causes the orange colouring in beavers’ teeth, makes the teeth stronger against mechanical stress, and makes them more resistant to acid.

Beavers build dams for myriad reasons, and one is so that the lake behind it will grow deep enough to ensure it doesn’t freeze all the way through during the winter. This bit of temperature control is especially crucial because beavers anchor a food cache to the bottom of the lake to serve as sustenance during the cold months.

Beavers travel good distances from their homes to find food. If they find a good source, they build canals to the food source as a way to float the food back to their lodges. Logs and twigs are stored underwater for winter feeding.

A beaver’s activity is not synchronized with the typical solar day. Light levels in a beaver’s lodge and underwater remain consistently low throughout a 24-hour day. Without cues from the sun, a beaver’s circadian rhythm, or regular day cycle, changes. Its “days” become longer, often varying in length from 26-29 hours. Beavers are primarily nocturnal and tend to be most active at night.
Beavers are one of the few animals that modify their habitat Beavers build watertight dams made of woven sticks, reeds, branches and saplings caulked together with mud and rocks.
Beavers are known for building dams, which create ponds providing habitats for various wildlife.
They have powerful front teeth that never stop growing, allowing them to gnaw through trees.
Beavers are the second largest rodents in the world, after capybaras.
Their large, flat tails are used for balance, fat storage, and communication.
Beavers have webbed feet, making them excellent swimmers capable of staying underwater for up to 15 minutes.
They construct lodges in the middle of ponds with underwater entrances to keep predators out.
Beavers play a crucial role in maintaining wetlands, which help filter water and reduce flooding.
They primarily eat tree bark and aquatic plants, with willow, birch, and maple being their favorites.
Beavers are monogamous, typically mating for life and raising their kits together.
North American beavers can reach up to 60 pounds in weight, while their Eurasian counterparts are slightly smaller.
